August 13, 1943
Dear Gertie,
Your heavenly letter of August 7th. arrived today
with all the news of your doings. I am certain y u will
feel much better at Watch Hill in the sunshine and taking
a certain amount of exercise. It is the type of life you have
always liked and the one at which you feel the best.
The children sound very sweet. I wish I could see
them together. They must be very brown and healthy, while your
description of Honey makes me want to take him in my arms and
give him a great big hug. He must feel that life at last is giv
ing him a wonderful time and he probably wonders how long it will
last. He is really such a sweet dog that I hope there will
be a great deal of happiness in store for him and not to
much loneliness and kennels.
Please have Landine use our old cure for poison
Ivy the only one we ever found worked wonders within twenty
four hours. Do you remember[,]you rub the blisters until they
break with a three per cent solution of postassium permaganate.
Rub it well into the infection and it disappears almost overnight.
It stopped the irritation with you any number of times when it
seemed as if you were c tching it, and I know that it is so
much better than that calcimine solution that does nothing
but cover your face up with gue.
Morris returned tonight from his cruise an was very
glad to be in his room. He h wever had had a c bin to sleep in
and had spent the greater part of t_he day lying down and reading[,]
very unlike my having to pace the deck. However heagreeed with
me that the bor_edom is terrific, the absolut[e]lack of anything
to do drives one nuts. We feel we are very lucky in our present
jobs and hope that nothing changes them. I cannot transfer to
Your Business because as I told you in a previous letter all
request for l ave and transfer will be looked upon with suspicious
and it will be assumed that the offcer so requesting is
trying to avoid his duty. So say the powers that be in a written
letter. The great difference is that here you have a military
government. For example Morris left the car parked in the
wrong place before he left on his trip. We got a ticket and I
rang up and asked if we could pay the fine by check as it was
impossible to come in due to my duties. The answer was that
Morris was to appear before the military court an his return
and no one else would do and no one else could pay the fine.
He appears before a colonel whocan put any sentence on him that
he wishes. Military law is entirely different from civilian
and you cannot realize the difference until you [L]ive under it.
[End Page 1]
We cooked a wonderful dinner of canned chicken
a la king and birdseye xxxx lima beans. It was very good and
Morris said far tastier than the wretched fresh food they tried
toserve him on board the ship. It was a relief to have that old
godd metal[L]ic t[A]ste in his mouth again he said, and to know
that it came straight from the cannery to him w thout lying
open and subject to the hands of dirty cooks and mess boys.
The night before his return I stayed out at cincpac
and played tennisxwith some of the boys from the office and then
whnt to the movie there. F rst the Cincpac me[s]s was delightful.
Everything was spotless and the silver and linen looked so nice
that I wanted to just look at it. I had forgotten that things
could be so clean. The meal was served quickly and well by
mess men in newly starched jackets and the conversation at the
table was interesting and amusing. Afterwards we went to the
Cincpac movies and saw Leslie Howard in th story of the life
of Mitchell the man who invented the spitf[i]re. It was
thrilling from the point of view th t you saw this inventor
giving his life and knowing that he was giving it through
overwork in order that the spitfire might be ready for the
ba[t]tle of Britain that he knew was comming. There was a wonderful
s[c]en[e]where he walked into the British Vivkers Co after leaving his
doctor who had just told him that he could not live more than
ei[g]ht months if he did not go and take a years rest. The
Chariman of Vickers said to him "Mitchell we must have t he best
fighter in the world and we must have it within a year that is
all the time we c n give you". The inventor repeplied
"Gentlemen you will have it within eight months that is all the 
time I can give you." The play en_dedwith Churchills speech
"never xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx have so many owed so much to so
few".
Then there was a movie about the lost tre[a]sure of the
Incas that was absolutely astxounding. A[p]parently since the x
time of [C]ortes this treasure has been discovered four times and
each time the discovere returned to civilization only to die
speechless with some age old golden work in his hand. They show
you in the movie where the supposed entrance is to this
treasure. It is called the eagels nest. But no one who has ever
gone into that entrance has ever come out. Only the four men who
someoXhow stumbled on it return[ed]to civilization but die[d] before
they could tell where they had foundit.
Fat Face is furious because he is apartment bo[u]nd and
cannot go to the movies. Now that we live in this pest district
our movements are so confined that I am thinking of leaving
if they will let us until the epedemic breaks.
Goodbye sweetheart, all my love. You had better write
to the National City Bank in London, The american Embassy, and
the River club for mail I have sent there.
[End Page 2]
